results.title: Farm Newsreel No. 1
results.brief_description: This newsreel film features agricultural activities throughout Victoria, Australia. Activities featured include hop harvesting in Myrtleford, tobacco harvesting in Ovens Valley, onion harvesting in Colac, and silage distibution in Upper Pakenham.

results.title: The Mallee Research Station
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Ann Millard and Colin Webb
results.brief_description:
This film, made by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, was created to promote the ingenuity of agricultural scientists working at the Mallee Research Station in Walpeup, Victoria.

The film highlights the research station’s development of wheat production, sheep breeding and pasture improvements. It contains some wonderful examples of farm machinery and farming techniques of the era.

results.title: Welcome to my home
results.brief_description: Traces the history of the Aboriginal people of Weipa South since the time white men first arrived in 1606. The early influence of church and government is shown using historic footage and interviews with Aboriginal community leaders. Examines Aboriginal life there today and the interaction with the European settlement, which was established at Weipa to mine the bauxite deposit.

results.title: Understanding
results.creator_credit: Alasdair Clayre, Nigel Houghton, Patrick Lui and Peter Montagnon
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Heart of the Dragon”.
This program is Part Nine of a twelve episode documentary, The Heart of the Dragon. The documentary records what is actually happening in China today and it captures on film the lives of peasants, factory workers, Party officials, artists, scientists, and even millionaires.

results.title: Koalas: Out on a Limb
results.brief_description: A documentary that examines the situation of koalas in the wild. Healthy koalas in the Australian bush are a rare sight these days and there are several different factors that are contributing towards the rapid decline in the population. One of the main factors is venereal disease which causes many females to become infertile.

results.title: Street kids
results.creator_credit: Leigh Tilson, Rob Scott, Kent Chadwick, Film Victoria and York St Film Productions
results.brief_description: A documentary about homeless youths, some as young as 10, surviving by any means on the streets of Melbourne. Various young people are interviewed about their situation and their search for jobs and accommodation. Highlights the frustrations they face and the resultant temptation to fall into crime and prostitution in order to survive. Police and social workers who deal with these young people from day to day comment on the situation and how they attempt to alleviate the despair of those they encounter. Use of voice-overs (street kids talking about their lives) is very effective as well as disturbing. A courageous and compelling documentary.

results.title: Turning 18
results.creator_credit: Tony Wright, Penny Robins, Peter Kaufman, Open Channel Productions and Video Projects
results.brief_description: An amusing look at some serious issues that are related to turning eighteen - the age by which a person is legally recognised as an adult in this society. This program, subtitled, “Almost 20 Minutes” is a parody of the current affairs television program, “60 Minutes”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tony Wright, Penny Robins, Peter Kaufman, Open Channel Productions and Video Projects

results.title: Eager to Write (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Andrew Scollo, L Reichstein F'tion, Open Channel Productions and W Buckland F'tion
results.brief_description: For children, the process of learning to write is a gradual and experimental one. This program follows the progress of children of different ages in the classroom. Follows a Myer Foundation program at Moonee Ponds West Primary School with Lorraine Wilson.

results.title: Rhythm (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Lessons in visual language”.
Devised and narrated by Peter Thompson. Explores rhythm as a fundamental part of the language of motion pictures and its integral role in film making. Addresses: 1. Rhythm does not depend on cutting 2. Changes of shot do not necessarily have any special rhythmic effect 3. Music can impose its own rhythm 4. Music and images can work together. No other credits available.
